body.raw:
Hey, I'm Aulia Rahman, just a regular guy navigating the world of software engineering from the bustling streets of Jakarta, Indonesia. Right now, I'm grinding away at [GovTech Procurement](https://www.linkedin.com/company/govtech-procurement), where the tech challenges keep me on my toes.

But life's not just about work, you know? It's about the people who make it all worthwhile. I love kickin' back with my girlfriends, hanging out with my buddies, and soaking up that family love—it's the real good stuff.

Now, when I'm not glued to my laptop, you might catch me hitting the court for a game of basketball. There's something about the squeak of sneakers on the hardwood that just gets me going. And yeah, I'm into lifting weights too—not just for the gains, but for the mental clarity it brings.

I'm all about growth, not just in my code but in life. The tech world moves fast, and I'm here for it. Always eager to learn something new, always evolving because, let's face it, that's where the good stuff happens.

Come along for the ride as I figure out this software engineering maze, finding joy in the little things, and keeping it real. Let's connect, share, and grow—because life's too short for anything else.

document.title: A Simple Guide to Content Security Policy
document.description: Learn how to keep your website safe with Content Security Policy (CSP) in a nutshell.

body.raw:
Hey devs! 👋 Let's talk about something important for our websites—Content Security Policy (CSP). It's like a rulebook that helps keep our web projects safe from potential issues. Let's break it down.

## What's Content Security Policy?

CSP is like a set of rules for browsers to follow and protect our websites. It helps prevent common web problems, like Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) and unwanted content.

## How to Do CSP the Easy Way

### 1. Set the CSP Header

First things first, set the CSP header in your web server's response. This tells the browser what's allowed. For starters:

```html
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self';
```

This says only stuff from our own site is allowed by default.

### 2. Choose Where Stuff Comes From

Customize your CSP by choosing where different types of content can come from. For example:

```html
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self'
https://trusted-scripts.com;
```

This lets scripts come from our site and trusted-scripts.com.

### 3. Use Unique Codes (Nonces and Hashes)

Use unique codes like nonces and hashes to control inline scripts and styles. Make it unique each time for added security:

```html
Content-Security-Policy: script-src 'nonce-RANDOM-NONCE'
'sha256-HASH-OF-TRUSTED-SCRIPT';
```

### 4. Find Out If Something's Up

Want to know if someone's trying to mess with your policy? Turn on reporting:

```html
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; report-uri
/report-violations-endpoint;
```

## Why Bother with Content Security Policy?

- **Stopping Bad Scripts:** CSP helps keep malicious scripts away.

- **Less Risk of Sneaky Stuff:** By controlling what gets loaded, you're less likely to get unwanted surprises.

- **Boosting Overall Security:** It's like having a friendly guide for your web app.

## Wrapping It Up

Using Content Security Policy is like having a rulebook to avoid common web problems. Keep an eye on it, update as needed, and your website will be a safer place.

Stay safe, keep coding! 🛡️🚀

document.title: Hello World - First Post
document.description: The first blog post, and I'll tell you the reason why I created this blog.

body.raw:
I decided to start this personal blog because I felt like something was missing from my life as a software engineer without having my own digital space, haha. My previous blog was just for show and never really got the attention it deserved. This time, I want to make it more real and regularly share things like writings, bits of code, everyday discoveries (Today I Learned), and basically anything I feel like posting.

When thinking about how the blog should look, I went for a simple design. My old blog was too busy with fancy stuff to look cool. Now, I'm going for a more grown-up and focused look, keeping it simple and functional without too much decoration.

After figuring out the design, I picked the techie tools I'll use. So, I went with Next.js + Tailwind + Shadcn UI + Vercel. It's not just what I'm used to; it also helps speed up the whole creating process. I thought about using Astro, but I stuck with Next.js because I believe it can do some pretty cool stuff. Next on the list is connecting to a database, maybe TursoDB? Right now, all the content is kept in my local storage.

And here's a little secret: this blog will gradually receive new features if I'm not lazy (Mood Driven Development) 😅. I'm excited to see how this space evolves. Thanks for being part of this journey, and let's keep sharing what we know! 🙌
